technology.name: Building Information Modeling
technology.definition: Building Information Modeling (BIM) is a digital representation of physical and functional characteristics of a facility. A BIM is a shared knowledge resource for information about a facility forming a reliable basis for decisions during its life-cycle; defined as existing from earliest conception to demolition (National BIM Guide for Owners, 2017).
technology.general_requirements:
Access to laptop
Access to internet
License BIM software and tools
Trained employee
Hardware requirements
Owner’s project BIM goals
BIM Project Execution Plan (PxP)
Level of Development (LOD)
Roles and responsibilities of key project stakeholders with respect to information modeling
Compatible with the Owner's computer platform requirement
Capable of supporting current and legacy file formats
Agnostic
Able to support open, consensus standards to maximize future compatibility
technology.functions:
Existing Conditions
Design Authoring
Design Review
Cost Estimating
Site Analysis – Development
Site Utilization – For Construction
Codes and Standards Compliance
Asset Management
Project schedule
Material inventories

technology.name: Big data
technology.definition: Big data is a broad term for a complex and substantial collection of data, which needs advanced engineering strategies and analytics systems to process, store and manage. The term ‘‘big data’’ does not simply mean ‘‘a big amount’’ of data containing abundant information, which would be called ‘‘very large data’’ or ‘‘massive data’’. Essentially, ‘‘big data’’ stands for the data which are generally unstructured, heterogeneous, and therefore extremely complex to deal with (Li et al., 2023).
technology.general_requirements:
Real-time or nearly real-time analysis
Data security, privacy and protection
Data quality of construction industry datasets
Structured data
Development of an information management platform that manages all facets of a project’s operation
Internet connectivity
technology.functions:
Big data engineering (Data Acquisition, Data processing, Data storage, Database, Pipeline – to build complete and fluent workflow)
Big data analytics (Prediction, Classification, Clustering, Inference, Optimization

technology.name: Artificial Intelligence
technology.definition: Artificial intelligence denotes the science and engineering of creating intelligent machines that exhibit reasoning, learning, knowledge, communication, perception, planning, and the ability to move and operate objects (Darko et al., 2020).
technology.general_requirements:
Skilled and trained workforce
Available data, of suitable quality, and at the right level of detail to support the business problem
Data storage system
High computing capacity
Networking infrastructure
Data security and protection
technology.functions:
Expert Systems
Problem Solving and Planning
Natural Language Processing
Controlling of robots
Computer Vision
Machine learning
Genetic Algorithm Optimization
Artificial Neural Networks
Fuzzy logic
Nonmonotonic reasoning

technology.name: Extended Reality
technology.definition: Extended reality (XR) is the umbrella term for a spectrum of immersive and interactive technologies. It encompasses augmented reality (AR), mixed reality (MR), and virtual reality (VR) (J. Link, 2022). Virtual Reality is a computer technology that gives users an illusion of being immersed in a virtual environment. Fundamentally, VR enables a computer simulation of real situation where human subject may interact with the virtual environment . AR is regarded as a channel between VR and telepresence as it magnifies realism rather than substitute it . AR can be defined as the amplification of the real environment with data from the virtual environment, that is, augmenting reality with virtuality (“Automation and Robotics in the Architecture, Engineering, and Construction Industry,” 2022). Mixed reality is the combination of augmented and virtual reality, creating spaces for the interaction of objects, people and virtual scenarios with the real ones (F. Munoz-La Rivera; et al., 2021).
technology.general_requirements:
VR or AR glasses/headset
Display devices (tablets)
Skilled workforce
5G networks
Powerful desktop or laptop PC
technology.functions:
Virtual learning and training environment
Site layout visualization
Simulation of hazardous construction scenarios
Expedite construction activities
Usability reviews in the early stages of the project
Work interactively in real-time and at scale
Coordination of systems and their components
Identifying spaces through virtual labelling
Facilitating the logistics of materials and equipment on-site

technology.name: Geographic information system
technology.definition: Geographic Information System (GIS) is a computer-based tool used for capturing, storing, quarrying, analyzing and displaying the geographic information. GIS activities may be grouped into spatial and attribute data management, data display, data exploration, data analysis and modeling (V. K. Bansal, 2007). Spatial or spatio-temporal statistical modelling for the analysis of patterns and exploration of relationships, which are primarily collected by geodesy methods. One of the primary products of ﬁeld geodesy work is topographic maps with large spatial scales indicating terrain characteristics, infrastructure, buildings and land cover. After digitization of topographic maps, spatial data depicting  natural attributes become data layers of GIS (Song et al., 2017).
technology.general_requirements:
Computer system
GIS software
Trained workforce
Required level and amount of building information in the geospatial environment
City Geography Markup Language (CityGML) or similar standards
technology.functions:
Capturing geographic information
Storing geographic information
Quarrying geographic information
Analyzing geographic information
Displaying the geographic information
Photo documentation
technology.examples:
ArcGIS
QGIS 3
Hexagon Geomedia
MapInfo Professional

technology.name: Photogrammetry
technology.definition: Photogrammetry is the art and science of extracting 3D information from photographs. The process involves taking overlapping photographs of an object, structure, or space, and converting them into 2D or 3D digital models. There are two primary types of photogrammetry: aerial and close-range (Autodesk, n.d.).
technology.general_requirements:
Cameras
Photogrammetry software
Data storage
Reduced static and dynamic occlusion
Internet access
Photogrammetric calibration, which requires prerequisite knowledge of the physical object
Analyzed elements to be visible from multiple (at least two) diﬀerent points of view
technology.functions:
Create topographic maps
Create meshes
Create point clouds (digital reconstruction)
Create drawings based on the real-world
Obtain geometric properties of objects and their spatial location

technology.name: Simulation models and tools
technology.definition: Building simulation is a way to test how elements of building design will perform under real-world conditions. This is done using a mathematical model that re-creates conditions in a virtual environment (N. Khan, 2023).
technology.general_requirements:
Problem formulation
Collection of information and documentation of assumptions
Validation of assumptions
Simulation Execution Approach
Simulation Result Representation
Integration Requirements
Complete Project Modeling
Model Reusability Support
Validation of programmed model
User Friendly Software
technology.functions:
Replicate real-world scenarios
Predict outcomes
Project modeling and optimization

technology.name: Cloud computing
technology.definition: Cloud computing is a model for enabling ubiquitous, convenient, on-demand network access to a shared pool of configurable computing resources (e.g., networks, servers, storage, applications, and  services) that can be rapidly provisioned and released with minimal management effort or service provider interaction. This cloud model is composed of five essential characteristics, three service models, and four deployment models (The NIST Definition of Cloud Computing, n.d.).
technology.general_requirements:
Application Performance Monitoring (APM) tools
Cloud provider
Service Level Agreement with cloud providers
Data privacy and security
Defined access level for the different category of stakeholders involved in the production and management of building data
Internet connectivity
Skilled workforce
technology.functions:
On-demand scalability of computing resources
Providing real-time access to data from any location
Secured platform
Massive storage for acquired data
Real time collaborative construction environment
Integration of construction supply chains
technology.examples:
Google Cloud
Oracle Cloud
IBM Cloud
Amazon Web Services
Microsoft Azure

technology.name: Automated regulation checking and audits
technology.definition:
The compliance checking process occurs constantly throughout all phases of a project lifecycle in the AECO (Architecture, Engineering, Construction, and Operation) domain and affects all aspects of the lifecycle. There are essentially two main ingredients or data sources in a typical automated compliance checking (ACC) process, namely:
1. The building model, a digital representation of the design data, which is subject to audit for compliance.
2. Normative knowledge, a computable representation of normative provisions stipulated by codes and standards, which is the baseline for the audit (Amor & Dimyadi, 2021).
technology.general_requirements:
BIM-enrichment techniques (make a BIM model more readily processable for speciﬁc applications such as compliance checking by automatically adding required objects and attributes)
Modelling and representation of normative provisions as computable rules by knowledge acquisition and knowledge engineering
BIM standards for the models Consenting authorities will be accepting
Correct and consistent classiﬁcation of information
Form of contract to ensure the extra modelling effort is recognized and compensated when ACCS is in place
Computer interpretable format of codes and standards need to be equivalent to the original paper-based versions
Process notation to direct the checking process
technology.functions:
Automate the review processes of engineering designs according to regulations and design codes
Processes of control and monitoring of construction projects and asset management
Quality assurance and quality control

technology.name: Common Data Environment
technology.definition: The common data environment (CDE) is a central repository where construction project information is housed. The contents of the CDE are not limited to assets created in a ‘BIM environment’ and it will therefore include documentation, graphical model and non-graphical assets (R. McPartland, 2016).
technology.general_requirements:
Domain-specific approach (model authors have full access only to the domain specific sub-model they are responsible for)
Federated model approach (provides a central coordination model)
Quality check of the model for compliance with the standards and codes (quality gate)
Agreed project standards (set of legally binding requirements for the way data is stored)
Author's awareness about project standards and basic knowledge on data handling
Employer's Information Requirements
Connection to BIM authoring tool
Locking mechanism to handle simultaneous data access
BIM Collaboration Format (BFC)
Well-defined workflow
Unique identifier for every “information container” and a standard naming convention
Assigning a “suitability status” to all data
Controlling data revisions to ensure past revisions aren’t actively being used
A server for your project, or perhaps an extranet or some other form of file-based retrieval system
technology.functions:
Storage, retrieval and transfer of information models
Central data management tool
Connecting teams, models and project data in one environment
Providing one central data source for projects

technology.name: Edge computing
technology.definition: The core concept of edge computing is that the location of computing is close to the source of data and closer to users.  Edge computing is also a kind of distributed computing pattern: collected data can be processed at the smart gateway which is closer to users, without uploading a large amount of data to the cloud center. Edge computing is a favorable complement and effective extension of cloud computing. Cloud computing needs edge computing nodes to pre-process data, while edge computing needs massive storage and strong computing capacity of cloud computing as its support to break the bottleneck of network bandwidth and latency (Ning et al., 2020).
technology.general_requirements:
Included network related metrics and performance (such as high bandwidth and low latency communication infrastructure.)
Defined dependability attributes (non-functional requirements, such as Quality of Service, reliability, availability, security, safety, maintainability, integrity, etc.)
Computing resources: processing power, memory, storage capacity
Edge computing platform deployment
Maintenance of edge computing platform
Virtualization technology
Distributed storage management system
technology.functions:
Facilitate smart IoT applications
Execution of various container-based applications in proximity of the construction site
Relieving pressure of network bandwidth and data center
Enhancing the response speed of user request services
Improving the users’ authority to control private data
technology.examples:
Edge computing platform for internet users (AWS Greengrass, Microsoft Azure IoT, Baidu BIE, etc.)
Edge computing platform for Industrial Internet of Things (GE, Siemens, ABB, Schneider, Bosch)

technology.name: Robots
technology.definition: Robots are highly automated devices that carry out physical activities in the real world. Robots are used for highly specialized tasks, taking shapes most suitable for their use and not necessarily the humanoid shape, and they interact with the environment using sensors and actuators.(Abioye et al., 2021). Single-Task Construction Robots are systems that support workers on the construction site in executing one specific construction process or task (e.g., digging, concrete levelling, painting) or by completely substituting the physical activity of human workers necessary to perform this one process or task. The processes and tasks assisted or executed by STCRs are in most cases relatively profession or craft specific. (Bock & Linner, 2016).
technology.general_requirements:
Working direction of the system (along the facade, from overhead, etc.)
Mobility approach (omnidirectional mobile platform, rail guided, fixed, etc.)
Kinematic structure (number of degrees of freedom [DoFs], geometric organization of links, etc.)
End-effector design (level of inbuilt dexterity, etc.)
Modularity of the system (exchangeability of end-effectors, drive units, and other parts)
Control mode (remote controlled/supervised, automatic, human–robot cooperative)
Integrated with other construction processes, which demands safety measurements
Skilled workforce
Robot-oriented design of the building systems and components
Use of such systems to be considered with the conventional job site installation (e.g. parking or recharging stations for robots
Compatible with or integrated with upstream or downstream processes
technology.functions:
Automated Site-Measuring and Construction Progress Monitoring
Earth and foundation work robots
Robotized conventional construction machines (dumpers, haulers, excavators, etc.)
Reinforcement production and positioning
Automated/robotic 3D concrete structure production on the site
Automated/robotic 3D truss/steel structure assembly on the site
Bricklaying robots
Concrete distribution robots
Concrete levelling and compaction robots
Concrete finishing robots
Site logistics robots
Aerial robots for building structure assembly
Swarm robotics and self-assembling building structures
Robots for positioning of components (crane end-effectors)
Steel welding robots
Facade installation robots
Tile setting and floor finishing robots
Facade coating and painting robots
Humanoid construction robots
Exoskeletons wearable robots and assistive devices
Interior finishing robots
Fireproof coating robots
Service, maintenance, and inspection robots
Renovation and recycling robots
Mechanical support to worker's body
Helping workers to lift heavy loads

RICAL – Robotics and Intelligent Construction Automation Laboratory
Irma3D
Clearpath Robotics: Warthog unmanned ground vehicle
Clearpath Robotics: Husky unmanned ground vehicle
Clearpath Robotics: Ridgeback omnidirectional platform
Clearpath Robotics: Dingo indoor robotic platform

technology.name: Internet of things
technology.definition: Internet of things can be defined as a network of interconnected physical devices, like sensors, drones, 3D laser scanner, wearable and mobile devices, radio frequency identification devices (RFID), which is attached to construction resources to collect real-time data about the operational status of the project (Pan & Zhang, 2021). The three-layered architecture of IoT consists of 1) Perception layer,2) Network layer, and 3) Application layer. The perception layer which includes the perception nodes and perception networks is integrated into the target and is responsible for sensing and data collection. The network layer is responsible for data transportation, which is the most important layer in the architecture, as it is the convergence of various devices (e.g. gateway) and communication infrastructure. Finally, the application layer is the top layer which end users interact with. It receives the data transmitted and presents to users for further services (Jia et al., 2019).
technology.general_requirements:
5G wireless communication
Sensors
Mobile devices br>Semantic web and relational database (one of the most promising methods to facilitate IoT deployment in the construction industry)
Standards for information integration and management (to sort large and heterogeneous data sets into usable order)
Network layer: Wi-fi; Bluetooth; Zigbee; Long-Term Evolution (LTE).
User Interface
technology.functions:
Monitoring products and processes
Facility management
Localization
Resources tracking

technology.name: Cyber-Physical Systems/Embedded Systems
technology.definition: Cyber-Physical Systems represent tight integration of physical systems with their virtual representations to develop context-aware integrated analytical systems able to adapt to changes in the physical construction site/facility. Such systems bridge the virtual world with the physical world using sensors/data acquisition technologies and actuators to form closed-loop or feedback systems. CPS consist of two principal elements, the “physical to cyber” bridge and the “cyber to physical” bridge (Anumba et al., 2021).
technology.general_requirements:
Data capture systems
Internet and wireless communication networks
Local database and database server, and also enables processing of these data via control applications
Application programming interface (API, installed on portable devices for easy communication with the construction workers)
Real-time exchange of information
technology.functions:
Bi-directional coordination between virtual models and physical construction
Real time monitoring system
Component tracking

technology.name: Laser Scanners
technology.definition: Laser scanning, also known as high-deﬁnition surveying (HDS) or reality capture, is a means of using a laser to map an area with high accuracy. The acquired data provide construction professionals with what is known as a “point cloud”, which is a database connecting points in a 3D coordinate system.  3D point cloud data from 3D laser scanners are able to capture the surface geometries of target objects in an accurate and efﬁcient manner, and provide accurate and fast records of the 3D geometries of construction-related objects (Almukhtar et al., 2021).
technology.general_requirements:
Maximum range (m)
Minimum range (m)
Field of view (degree)
Scanning speed
Scan duration (seconds)
Scan accuracy (mm)
Laser beam diameter (mm)
Data storage
Station points locations on site
Determined required point cloud data quality for each speciﬁc application to facilitate the acquisition of point cloud data
Software for Exporting Scanning Data
technology.functions:
Collect three-dimensional (3D) coordinates of existing buildings
Restore original building information into 3D models
technology.examples:
Trimble TX8
Intel Real Sense
FARO Focus Laser Scanners
Measurement in Motion

technology.name: Sensors
technology.definition:
A sensor is a device or transducer that receives information about various physical effects, such as mechanical, optical, electrical, acoustic, and magnetic effects and converts that information into electrical signals. These electrical signals can be acted upon by the control unit (Chen, 2003). Research developed around specific capabilities of sensing devices can be broadly classified, non-exhaustively, into the following categories, detailed with illustrative examples (Louis & Dunston, 2018):
1. Vision-based techniques: this class of methodologies uses cameras
2. Ranging-based techniques: These techniques use light detection and ranging (LiDAR) and laser distance and ranging (LADAR)
3. Location-based tracking: This category of applications utilizes localization systems such as Global Positioning System (GPS) and ultrawide band (UWB)
technology.general_requirements:
Privacy and data security
raining and skills development for workforce
Signal processing
Digital control and manipulation
External communication and bus interaction
Defined Range
Accuracy Class
Sophisticated controllers and algorithms are necessary for dexterity, precision, and repetition require signals to be interpreted quickly or even in real time
technology.functions:
Real-time positioning
Real-time data collection during operation
Equipment health monitoring
Work quality verification and remediation
Collision-free path planning
Equipment performance measurement
Effectively track and manage their assets like tools, equipment, materials and prefabricated building components
Inventory management and theft prevention
Generate a description of the environment and the state of the robot system
Provide real-time health and safety results to construction personnel
Measure a wide variety of safety performance metrics, including blood oxygen, blood pressure, heart rate, proximity detection, respiratory rate, and worker location tracking
Access control
technology.examples:
GPS (basic, differential, kinematic)
RF/wi-ﬁ,bluetooth
RF/wide band
Laser indoor GPS
Magnetometers
Magnetic ﬁeld 6D positioning
Laser (tachymeters, trackers)
Optical trackers
Micro Electro Mechanical System based Inertial positioning
Camera positioning
